Growing up in the tropics, we always do one thing to pineapple before we eat it: Sprinkle salt on the cut pieces, mix the salt in and left it for half an hour before eating them.
When I migrated out, I found people don't do the salt thing and I thought, "Ok, maybe the pineapple here is different?"
Nope, they just didn't know about the bromelain. You really have to get rid most of the bromelain if you want to eat it straight up otherwise you can only eat a few pieces. Salt/salt water or heat (cooking/baking/grilling/etc.) works.

When visiting our military daughter while she was stationed in Hawaii, we all went on a ‘Dole Pineapple Plantation’ tour. I hadn’t known that the pineapple would be growing on the ground......... as if they had just been abandoned there!! They have fresh picked pineapples (which have the lowest acidity ‘burn’) that are made ready to be given out as free samples. They had a reddish-brown powder sprinkled over these samples. Oh my, those were the very best pineapples that we had ever eaten. That powder (called Li Hing, was in bags for sale) and it is a bit salty so it reduces the fruits acidity even more and adds to the flavor.
FYI: that Li Hing powder was responsible for making my daughter who hated pineapples, into one that loved it for the whole time that she was stationed there.

Just a side note. A (now redundant) test used in cross matching blood used proteolytic enzymes to expose what are known as cryptantigens. That is, the recipient may have preformed antibodies which can lead to a transfusion reaction which may not be otherwise detected in a test. Papain, derived from papaya, and used as a meat tenderiser, was the preferred enzyme, bromelain being considered too dangerous to the person doing the test. But that doesn't seem to be any obstacle to the "health food" industry, who sell the stuff (presumably quite dilute) as a nutritional supplement.

It's worth noting that canned pineapple and fruit cup pineapple has been heat treated such that the bromelain no longer functions. It's only fresh pineapple that eats you back.
This distinction is also why you can't use fresh pineapple with jello, the bromelain just slices up the gelatin, but canned works fine.
